medical: PREOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS: Severely comminuted fracture of the distal radius, left. POSTOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS: Severely comminuted fracture of the distal radius, left. OPERATIVE PROCEDURE: Open reduction and internal fixation, high grade Frykman VIII distal radius fracture. ANESTHESIA: General endotracheal. PREOPERATIVE INDICATIONS: This is a 52-year-old patient of mine who I have repaired both shoulder rotator cuffs, the most recent one in the calendar year 2007. While he was climbing a ladder recently in the immediate postop stage, he fell suffering the aforementioned heavily comminuted Frykman fracture. This fracture had a fragment that extended in the distal radial ulnar joint, a die-punch fragment in the center of the radius. The ulnar styloid and the radial styloid were off and there were severe dorsal comminutions. He presented to my office the morning of April 3, 2007, having had a left reduction done elsewhere a day ago. The reduction, although adequate, had allowed for the fragments to settle and I discussed with him the severity of the injury on a scale of 1-8, this was essentially an 8. The best results have been either with external fixation or internal fixation, most recently volar plating of a locking variety has been popular, and I felt that this would be appropriate in his case. Risks and benefits otherwise described were bleeding, infection, need to do operative revise or removal of hardware. He is taking a job out of state in the next couple of months. Hence I felt that even with close followup, this is a particularly difficult fracture as far as the morbidity of the injury proceeds. OPERATIVE NOTE: After adequate general endotracheal anesthesia was obtained, one gram of Ancef was given intravenously. The left upper extremity was prepped and draped in supine position with the left hand in the arm table, magnification was used throughout. The time out procedure was done to the satisfaction of all present that this was indeed the appropriate extremity on the appropriate patient. A small C-arm was brought in to help guide the incision which was a volar curvilinear incision that included as part of this due to the fracture blisters eminent compartment syndrome and numbness in fingers. A carpal tunnel release was done with the transverse carpal ligament being protected with a Freer elevator. The usual amount of dissection of the pronator quadratus was necessary to view the distal radial fragment. The pronator quadratus actually grasped several of the fragments itself which had to be dissected free from them, specifically the distal radial ulnar joint and die-punch fragment. At this point, a locking Synthes distal radius plate from the modular handset was selected that had five articular screws as well as five locking shaft screws. The ulnar styloid was not affixed in any portion of this repair. The plate was viewed under the image intensification device, i.e., x-ray and the screws were placed in this order. The most proximal shaft screw was placed to allow the remainder of the plate to form a buttress to then rearrange the fragments around the locking screws and a locking plate having been selected from the volar approach, a locking 12-mm screw through 16-mm screws were placed in the following order. Most proximal on the radial shaft of the plate, then the radial styloid, i.e., the most distal and lateral screw, the next most proximal shaft screw followed by the distal radial ulnar joint screw. Three screws were locking across the die-punch fragment. The remaining two screws were placed into the radial shaft. All of these were locking screws of 2 mm in diameter and as the construct was created, the relative motion of the intra-articular fragment in dorsal comminution all diminished greatly, although the exposure as well as the amount of reduction force used was substantial. The tourniquet time was 1.5 hours. At this point, the tourniquet was let down. The entire construct was irrigated with copious amounts of bacitracin and normal saline. Closure was affected with 0 Vicryl underneath the skin surface followed by 3-0 Prolene in interrupted sutures in the volar wound. Several image intensification x-rays were taken at the conclusion of the case to check screw length. Screw lengths were changed out during the case as needed based on the x-ray findings. The wound was injected with Marcaine, lidocaine, Depo-Medrol, and Kantrex. A very heavily padded fluffy cotton Jones-type dressing was applied with a volar splint. Estimated blood loss was 10 mL. There were no specimens. Tourniquet time was 1.5 hours.
layman:
**Pre‑operative diagnosis:**  
The left wrist has a badly broken distal radius (the bone near the wrist) with many small fragments.

**Post‑operative diagnosis:**  
Same as above – a severely broken distal radius on the left side.

**Operative procedure:**  
Open surgery to realign the bone and fix it with metal plates and screws (high‑grade Frykman VIII fracture).

**Anesthesia:**  
General anesthesia with a breathing tube.

**Pre‑operative indications:**  
The patient is 52 years old. He has had both shoulder rotator cuffs repaired before, most recently in 2007. While climbing a ladder, he fell and broke his left wrist in the same way described. The break had a fragment that extended into the joint between the radius and ulna, a “die‑punch” fragment in the middle of the radius, and the tips of the ulna and radius were displaced. There was also severe back‑side comminution (many small pieces). He came to my office on April 3, 2007 after a reduction (realignment) was done elsewhere the day before. That reduction was okay but the fragments had settled. I explained that the injury was very severe (rated 8 out of 8). The best treatments are either external fixation or internal fixation; the most recent popular method is a volar locking plate. I chose that for him. I explained the risks and benefits, including bleeding, infection, possible need for another surgery or removal of hardware. He will be working out of state in a few months, so close follow‑up will be difficult. This fracture is very difficult and has a high chance of complications.

**Operative note:**  
After general anesthesia was started, 1 g of Ancef was given IV. The left arm was cleaned and draped while the patient lay on his back. The left hand was placed on the arm table. We used a small C‑arm (X‑ray machine) to guide the incision. A curved incision was made on the palm side of the wrist. Because of the fracture blisters, possible compartment syndrome, and numb fingers, a carpal tunnel release was also performed. The transverse carpal ligament was protected with a Freer elevator. We dissected the pronator quadratus muscle enough to see the distal radius fragment. The muscle had grabbed several fragments, which we freed, especially the joint fragment and the die‑punch fragment.  

We chose a locking Synthes distal radius plate with five screws that go into the joint and five locking screws that go into the shaft. The ulna tip was not fixed. The plate was positioned under X‑ray guidance and screws were inserted in this order: the most proximal shaft screw first to create a buttress, then the rest of the plate was arranged around the locking screws. We used a 12‑mm locking screw through a 16‑mm hole for the most proximal shaft screw, then the radial styloid screw (most distal and lateral), then the next proximal shaft screw, then the joint screw. Three locking screws went across the die‑punch fragment. The remaining two screws went into the shaft. All screws were 2 mm locking screws. As we built the construct, the motion of the back‑side fragments was greatly reduced, although the exposure and reduction force were substantial.  

The tourniquet was on for 1.5 hours. It was released, and the area was washed with bacitracin and normal saline. Closure was done with 0 Vicryl under the skin and 3‑0 Prolene on the surface in interrupted stitches. Several X‑rays were taken at the end to check screw length; screw lengths were changed during the case as needed. The wound was injected with Marcaine, lidocaine, Depo‑Medrol, and Kantrex. A heavily padded cotton dressing (Jones‑type) and a volar splint were applied. Estimated blood loss was 10 mL. No tissue samples were taken. Tourniquet time was 1.5 hours.
